I stopped reading past;

on this occasion because if you didn’t realise what I posed was hypothetical you’re being abundantly stupid now. If it’s assumed it’s hypothetical, please never make me cringe like that again. It’s an insult to both of us.

“I’m saying it is more of what they would lose if they’d release it now.”

“Perfect dream worlds” Do you know what democracy is striving for? Do you understand the developments we’ve made as a race in the name of hypothetical dream worlds? Are you mocking me for that? Give me a break. If you think we’ve peaked as society you are one naive individual. If the human race is too survive at all I think you’ll find corporatism will be gone in a few centuries, otherwise by that time we’ll have all killed ourselves for the imaginary money people like you seem to value so much.

Also, in case you hadn’t noticed, the article in OP is completely hypothetical.

item.title: Bye Bye DVDs
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

I’m discussing business and profit because it is a fundamental part of manufacturing. Unless you’re sat here making hypothetical dream worlds up where a business doesn’t need profit and everyone lives happily together sharing their technology, what you’re saying makes no sense at all. You complained about them holding it back to purposely profit later on, implying they do have something to gain from not releasing it now. I’m saying it is more of what they would lose if they’d release it now. You brought up profit, I replied to that.

If they didn't care about profit they'd release it, or do you not see that? Do you not see the repercussions?.. If it's shelved there's no reason for pioneering research into newer technology - sure there is some - but there'd be a lot more if the bar was constantly being raised.

A technology doesn’t have to be released into mass production for that. The research has been done, that can be built upon afterwards in other products if a business doesn’t see the need to take a loss and mass produce it for a market that doesn’t want it.

But again, unless you’re living in a perfect dream world, few companies would do that, they put money into research and development in order to later make a profit on it their products. If they had to force a product out into a market that wasn’t ready for it, or just didn’t want it, they’d be losing money on that. Then they wouldn’t continue throwing mass amounts of money into R&D and then the bar wouldn’t be any higher than before, and in fact, it would probably make companies more cautious about their R&D.

Competition raises the bar for new technology. Technology in a consumer or professional product that makes profit, it what makes other companies put research into makes products better than theirs, and also release relevant technologies, which HVD isn’t. So i’d argue that no, Lothy’s suggestion wouldn’t be best for the industry, now, I also don’t like how the patent system works at the moment either, but releasing people’s patents after a certain amount of time of inactivity (if they never did anything with them) wouldn’t be the answer either, people would just stop publicly showing their technology and patenting it.

It isn’t just them trying to profit from it. It is companies knowing that there isn’t a market for it yet. By 2007 Blu-ray had been pretty much confirmed as the industry standard, significant investment had already been put into it and it was already out there.

Them bringing it out now, or then would have seen it flop.
